posts.name: Tamir Cohen
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone!

I’ve been designing an infinite recharge robot as a personal project, and I want to include a spindexer. However, I’m having some trouble figuring out how different spindexer designs function.

I understand most of them have a pulley or sprocket at the bottom which hooks up to a motor, but how are the spindexers supported? Are they usually on a large lazy susan? I’ve seen spindexers which are sandwiched between bearings at the center (like 148’s), is that the only thing supporting them?

I keep looking for spindexer CADs and can’t find any! I’d love some help with this. Thanks!

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Our was NOT the best. But it was a fun project to work on during pandemic school and the 2021 ‘season’.

Team 4276 "free" spindexer upgrade Robot Showcase

Here is my best attempt at making the CAD available in grabcad: https://workbench.grabcad.com/workbench/projects/gcIrFZVuo001jtnF5CuuCxHFBbUmS_F7v809al_xjb92Xz#/space/gcsaKCdj0C95-SIUvumVMFkLDIisK-N1BIMO7bHdAPbGUa

posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Some resources which might be helpful that came to mind:

https://youtu.be/g37nszdgPMs?t=194 - this one’s clear, you can see the driven wheel which rotates the platform, looks like it rides on low friction skids on frame/bellypan.

Poofs tech binder and associated CD thread (lots of answered questions here).

The Rembrants have a - ton - of - videos from their 2020 prototyping process (around January 2020) testing out a spindexer design. I don’t think they ended up fielding this concept, but the videos are likely to be very informative on how the mechanism works / could be implemented, since it’s an isolated mockup that they iterate through hand demonstrate problems with: https://www.youtube.com/c/Teamrembrandts/videos

That said, Its always worth reaching out to teams directly and asking about areas you don’t understand, and seeing if there are design changes they would recommend. Often there’s improvements people would choose to make if they had to start over that never made it to the field for whatever reason (time, cost, weight).

Find a design you like/think would integrate well on your robot. Study it. And then shoot an email/message off to the team. Most teams are willing & excited to help answer questions and elevate your knowledge on their implementations.

posts.cooked:

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
otherguy:

That said, Its always worth reaching out to teams directly and asking about areas you don’t understand, and seeing if there are design changes they would recommend. Often there’s improvements people would choose to make if they had to start over that never made it to the field for whatever reason (time, cost, weight).

Yes. Reach out. Every team I have asked has been generous with their time. There is lots of information that cannot be conveyed via a CAD model or a match/reveal video. Often, that is the information that makes the difference between a mechanism that works well and one that looks like one that works well but doesn’t.
I joined my team recently, but I know that their design had a big lazy susan.

posts.name: Noah Bistline
posts.cooked:
(3) FRC team 1690 Orbit 2020 robot reveal - “CHESTER” - YouTube

Great and fun design for a team!

We tried doing one the fall of last year, but we just couldn’t get it ( diagnosis was that we designed the spindexer around the robot - not the other way around ).

We at one point were experiencing problems with power cells not riding pick-up smoothly, and not aligning consistently. We reached out to the incredible 1690 , as they were our “inspiration”, and they gave us numerous details - although I don’t have them written down any more, I’m sure they would be happy to help if you reached out. I’ll return to this thread with design tips once my ducks are in a row. For now, check out the video . Its their reveal, and does a fantastic job of showcasing their job.

link_counts.title: FRC team 1690 Orbit 2020 robot reveal - "CHESTER" - YouTube

posts.name: Paul Rensing
posts.cooked:
Our 2020/21 robot had a spindexer, which we called the carousel.  You should be able to see the details in the CAD: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/345cd55837615ef670627969/w/70c07d2f594af8957cf586af/e/2d396e9e9109f86935a49da4

Basically we created a squat cylinder out of very thin polycarb, and put 3D printed dividers inside. It was mounted on a lazy-susan and driven with a big belt (not sure if that properly in the CAD).
